reviews.review_msg: Great professor, his biggest issue is yapping, but he's a good professor, people who gave bad reviews should switch majors because the quizzes were reasonable and the assignments were moderate, it doesn't get easier from here on out.

5 tough, assignment that build on top of each other (don't mess up the first few) + final exam. Vague feedback, hard to debug old assignments, but instructor/TAs are very responsive. The instructor genuinely cares, but has high expectations for students. VERY coding heavy, prerequisites don't do it justice. Don't take with other heavy classes.

He was very fair and a decent prof for CMPT 300. No final exam, only two quizzes, 2nd quiz was not cumulative and covered material past the first quiz only. Majority of grade came from the 4 assignments we had to do, which were pretty doable. I believe 454 is his passion class hence the higher difficulty, but would take again for a class like 300

Great prof. 4 assignments + 2 MT for the grading, no finals which is awesome. Very knowledgeable and slides are detailed and easy to comprehend. Only issue was that the class was way too early in the morning, but that's more of a scheduling issue. Would take a course with Tianzheng again!

Honestly one of the best lecturers I have encountered in my degree so far. Dr. Wang was engaging, open to questions and very approachable. He made a notoriously hard course a breeze. Even though CMPT 300 will no longer be offered I would recommended taking any course with him as a professor.

I wish that we had homework or quizzes so that we can check how well we absorbed the materials before exams. The professor and TA really save their time by making no homework/quizzes/feedbacks, but it causes confusion for us students. It's reaally an awful learning experience for me.

Seems to me that the course has too many aims to achieve: both introductory ones and advanced ones. It's like one course trying to achieve two courses' goals. The professor just crams everything into the course without adjusting the workloads according to the limited time and students' levels.

He set high standards for students, but he didn't seem to spend enough time or make enough efforts to guarantee good logistics or fair grading. It left me the impression that our work was graded arbitrarily, in a hasty manner, and by few things.

While the professor said that he "really" wants to give us marks, the truth is rather the opposite. Minor mistakes in the projects, each can lead to deduction of 2-3 points in the final grade. So, if you have several minor mistakes, you might receive much lower-than-expected grade (for example, A- becomes B+ or B).

Some professors hold high expectations for students. However, they usually show a clear path of how to be successful in their courses by giving clear instructions. Wang's problem is not tough grading, but not giving useful instructions. You'll be surprised by the reasons why the marks are deducted.
Prof Wang is a tough grader. In fact, I haven't met any other professor at SFU who is so harsh in grading.

For knowledge: he didn't explain things well, and he skipped key concepts. Online resources can offer better learning experience.

For grade: Wang is an especially harsh grader to be avoided.

The course was not extremely bad, but the logistics was toxic. He changed his mind/policy many times without formal announcements, and certain policies were made just before the final deadline. I am not a fan of such lazy and disorganized manner.

Professor Wang never give us clear and up-front instructions so that we have a guideline of what's expected. The feedbacks are released too late. Without an idea of what are his actual requirements, you'll find his grading arbitrary. Seems that he graded at the last minute, and it's graded by few things.

Learning from a demanding, irresponsible, and unpredictable professor can be frustrating. If you really can't avoid him, you still can try to get the best scores from all other courses, and that will demonstrate to the world that you did excellent work, and the poor grading is his problem.

On average, you are expected to get B- or C+ from him, while other CS professors would give you an average of A-. It's not just some students are falling behind, it impacts everybody. The exceedingly low average grade clearly indicates that he can't teach well and he's just not responsible enough for teaching matters.

Some project topics require us to use high performance computers for experiments. No one tell you this, but you lose marks if you don't do it. I don't think it's fair that we got lower marks because of having no access to a good computer. I'm not satisfied that prof never make instructions clear and fair.

Surprised by the number of negative reviews. There is a lot of content covered but the lectures, projects and instructions are well organized and fair. Project builds on top of other modules so it can be difficult to catch up if something goes wrong early. Overall I enjoyed building the toy database and learnt a lot from the course.
Life is hard. Don't make it harder by learning with him. "Why is the score so low? What did you do?" "I worked hard but the professor is Tianzheng Wang. He's impossible."
Horrible. Maybe he's good at research, but he definitely doesn't care about teaching and students. Avoid if you can.

I'm grateful that I don't find a second GPA destroyer like this one at SFU. For those who want to learn database: he's not the only professor who teaches this course. You have better alternative options.
Prof Wang successfully minimizes his efforts and maximizes students' frustrations.

I strongly discourage you from taking his course. I can't think of another professor at SFU who gave me such bad learning experience. Our work was graded carelessly. Hardworking was not rewarded and minor mistakes can be punished harshly. Since there's no homework/instructions/grading criteria, we are punished for his laziness and awful logistics!

I've been at SFU for 4 yrs and I've overcome many difficult courses. I have confidence tackling difficult courses, not difficult professors. tzwang is definitely the most difficult professor (not one of) I've ever seen. He just made everything unnecessarily hard because he didn't do his job properly. He's second to none in creating low morale.

Taking course with him you'll get much heavier workload and much lower grade. But he did this for your good, right? Even if he doesn't explain things clearly and doesn't check details for fair grading, you did learn a lot and you'll have something funny on your transcript. Isn't that great? Isn't that the perfect course to take?

He didn't care if students absorb the lecture stuff. He didn't give useful, clear instructions. Some feedbacks were released too late, and grade was based on few things. I doubt if he put even minimal efforts in teaching.

He made the course unnecessarily hard by giving vague instruction, few feedback and non-sense grading. He has constantly proved that he's failing at teaching yet he's proud of that. Don't let this guy ruin your GPA or your confidence in learning database. Database is not difficult, he is. He would punish students for his own faults. JUST AVOID!!

Some graders are tough cuz they care about ur success in future. This one just grade by few things and pick out minor mistakes to deduct marks heavily. He doesn't care about students, just want to spend no time in teaching.

I have a rubric for prof wang. Being absent for 2 lectures: -2; Dismiss class before scheduled time >2 times: -2; No clear instructions before assignments: -4; Give low average grade without good reason: -4. Overall: -7/5. There's no rescale because that's not fair to other professors. I'd give a high score but this is the rightful thing to do.
This is the WORST prof at SFU. Giving him 1/5 rating is unfair to other professors receiving 1/5. His rating should be something like - 1/5.

Only those who have already learned the stuff before taking the course can get a merely fine grade. He's not teaching. He just wants everyone to be an expert and contribute to his own projects. Indeed he's lazy and irresponsible.

After midterm, he suggested those who earned 20%-30% in the exam to "work harder". He said that if you put everything there in the report it will be fine. It is funny and unrealistic. But it is also EVIL because he knew crystal clear in his mind that he won't let them pass and he still gave them false hope and tortured them.

Giving students extremely low scores is not a way to prove that "I am the best, I am too good to be at SFU". No clear instructions, few feedbacks, unrealistic syllabus/learning goals, requiring expertise as an intermediate course... these all indicate poor design of the course and neglect of students. It is so pathetic and pathological.

Difficulty should be 6 out of 5. Don't care to improve teaching, provide feedbacks, improve logistics, or make policies clear. Average grade is much lower than other courses at SFU. There are way better database courses online from really top professors. Work harder and get a lower grade from him is the last choice you might want.
First course that I failed in 4 years.
Disappointed
Terrible
One of the worst prof I've taken so far. His assignments are really difficult. This course also had a negative impact on my other courses. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM.
I am just astonished how misleading the reviews can be ... Look at those reviews below with full marks, then think about quite the opposite, which might be closer to reality.
Prof wang is good and helping but lectures are low quality which confused me many times. There is a lot of coding in this course and unrealistic difficult grading standards.

He's great. Lectures are efficient and very coherent. Most importantly, attendance is not required but participation is rewarded. Responsive and good choice of TAs. Assignments and quizzes are challenging and educational. Rare to find profs as good as he in SFU CS department.

Awesome prof. He explains the concepts quite well and if you have more questions he is approachable to ask. The database project is very hard and he warns us to be prepared and to drop if we find the first milestone really hard. (many people dropped and complained because they literally started milestones 1-2 days it was due and we had 3 weeks...)
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. THE DATABASE PROJECT IS DAMN NEAR IMPOSSIBLE. OVER 40% HAVE ALREADY DROPPED THE COURSE. IT'S ALL IN C AND GUESS WHAT THAT'S WHAT YOUR GRADE WILL BE.
he's the best prof you could take 300 with. He's very good at explaining the concepts. The assignments and exams were fair imo

Sometimes the lecture content can be a little too vague, but Dr. Wang is helpful if you ask further questions about stuff you didn't understand in office hours. No final exam, however the quizzes weren't easy. Reasonable assignments -- everything you implement is discussed in lectures. Despite earlier reviews, he was not very active on Piazza.

I liked the project where we built a database engine - it was good to see how to apply some of the theory (its a lot of locks). I do wish we implemented query parsers/optimizers. The lectures were long and a touch on the dry side (and i find many of the topics interesting).

Very project heavy, but you learn a lot. You implement a database and it's worth 85% of your mark, he also gives chance for bonus marks and if you do well he gives you a good mark, no scaling (his words). Quizzes weren't hard if you attended lectures and studied a tiny bit, no final. Learned a lot
Hard projects, quiz beyond expected difficulty

To be honest, this class was not for me. I am not a fan of low level programming or using C++. However, if this is what you do like, then you will love this class. The assignments are really tough if you do not know C++. The profs instructions were not extremely helpful. The lecture notes are also very dense, almost unreasonably so.

This is without a doubt THE best course currently offered that I have had the pleasure to take at SFU. The group project is well structured, but start early! tzwang has proven lecture after lecture that he really understands the content and can _easily_ answer any/all questions. His content is very well structured - one of the best profs at SFU!

You get to learn many programming techniques while doing the project, the class material is not hard but the challenge is to memorize all of them. as for the project, he literally said "if you can do well in this project, you can theoretically do well in any other programming project." So if you can survive, very interesting and useful class.

Incredibly fast replies on Piazza: 30 min after posting. His replies help you through the issue you're facing and assignment criteria is clear. Textbook is unnecessary. He provides his lecture notes and they're amazing! They go through everything you need for the tests, which accurately reflect course material. 10/10 would take his classes.
Just going to say one thing, he replies piazza questions faaaaaaastt :)
Easily one of the best professors I have had at SFU. He is super approachable, his lecture notes are amazing, and his midterms are more than fair.

Great prof, really clear up front what the grading scheme is and the schedule that he sets is pretty much bang on. He posts lectures notes online beforehand and posts the video lectures after. He is very approachable for questions. Only criticism is that assignments are marked too slowly. Course material is hard, but he is the best prof to take.

Very friendly and approachable professor, his lectures are relatively easy to follow. Exams are fairly easy. Assignts are highly related to the materials and are interesting to do (I really mean it), it's just too much work for only 6% . Take with him if you can handle 5 harder assignments and like easier exams.
this is the best professor I have ever taken in SFU his lecture is very clear and the assignment is highly related to the lecture, if you have a chance just take cmpt300 with him.
Makes the class significantly harder than it needs to be. Assigns very hard assignments and doesn't curve the class when everyone bombs the exams.
